Arg1.RawText: The economy does, however, depend on the confidence of businesses, consumers and foreign investors

Arg2.RawText: A panic on Wall Street doesn't exactly inspire confidence

Arg1.RawText: Surveys suggested that consumer confidence was high before Friday

Arg2.RawText: A 190-point drop isn't likely to make much of a dent

Arg1.RawText: multiply that a few times over, though, and it will

Arg2.RawText: If the reactions of executives gathered Saturday at Hot Springs, Va., for the Business Council meetings are typical, business leaders weren't overly rattled by Friday's decline

Arg1.RawText: On the bottom line, the most comforting fact for the economic outlook is that we've been through this before

Arg2.RawText: Two years ago, about the only point of comparison was the 1929 crash and the subsequent Depression

Arg1.RawText: Two years ago, about the only point of comparison was the 1929 crash and the subsequent Depression

Arg2.RawText: The doomsayers had a receptive audience

Arg1.RawText: The doomsayers had a receptive audience

Arg2.RawText: The prosperity that followed Black Monday permits a more optimistic view today

Arg1.RawText: At the very least, the establishment here is taking comfort from the nation's success in handling the last go-around

Arg2.RawText: As Sen. Lloyd Bentsen (D., Texas) observed yesterday, "The Fed avoided a meltdown last time.They are more sophisticated this time

Arg1.RawText: The Fed avoided a meltdown last time

Arg2.RawText: They are more sophisticated this time

Arg1.RawText: For some of these companies, this will be the first quarter with year-to-year negative comparisons

Arg2.RawText: This could be the first of five or six down quarters

Arg1.RawText: Perhaps most prominent, Dow Chemical Co is expected to report that profit decreased in the latest quarter from a year earlier, if only by a shade

Arg2.RawText: Though Dow has aggressively diversified into specialty chemicals and pharmaceuticals, the company still has a big stake in polyethylene

Arg1.RawText: Analysts' third-quarter estimates for the Midland, Mich., company are between $3.20 a share and $3.30 a share, compared with $3.36 a year ago, when profit was $632 million on sales of $4.15 billion

Arg2.RawText: A Dow spokeswoman declined to comment on the estimates

Arg1.RawText: At the investment firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., the commodity-chemical segment is seen pulling down overall profit for 20 companies representative of the whole industry by 8% to 10%

Arg2.RawText: You will find the commodities off more than the others and the diversified companies about even or slightly better," says James Wilbur, a Smith Barney analyst

Arg1.RawText: First Boston Corp. projects that 10 of the 15 companies it follows will report lower profit

Arg2.RawText: Most of the 10 have big commodity-chemical operations

Arg1.RawText: Still, some industry giants are expected to report continuing gains, largely because so much of their business is outside commodity chemicals

Arg2.RawText: Du Pont Co. is thought to have had steady profit growth in white pigments, fibers and polymers

Arg1.RawText: Analysts are divided over whether Du Pont will report much of a gain in the latest quarter from its Conoco Inc. oil company

Arg2.RawText: The estimates for Du Pont range from $2.25 to $2.45 a share

Arg1.RawText: The estimates for Du Pont range from $2.25 to $2.45 a share

Arg2.RawText: In the 1988 third quarter, the company earned $461 million, or $1.91 a share, on sales of $7.99 billion

Arg1.RawText: In the 1988 third quarter, the company earned $461 million, or $1.91 a share, on sales of $7.99 billion

Arg2.RawText: Du Pont declined to comment

Arg1.RawText: Monsanto Co., too, is expected to continue reporting higher profit, even though its sales of crop chemicals were hurt in the latest quarter by drought in northern Europe and the western U.S

Arg2.RawText: The St. Louis-based company is expected to report again that losses in its G.D. Searle & Co. pharmaceutical business are narrowing

Arg1.RawText: The St. Louis-based company is expected to report again that losses in its G.D. Searle & Co. pharmaceutical business are narrowing

Arg2.RawText: Searle continued to operate in the red through the first half of the year, but Monsanto has said it expects Searle to post a profit for all of 1989

Arg1.RawText: Most estimates for Monsanto run between $1.70 and $2 a share

Arg2.RawText: A year ago, the company posted third-quarter profit of $116 million, or $1.67 a share, on sales of $2.02 billion

Arg1.RawText: A year ago, the company posted third-quarter profit of $116 million, or $1.67 a share, on sales of $2.02 billion

Arg2.RawText: Monsanto declined to comment

Arg1.RawText: But the commodity-chemical producers are caught on the downside of a pricing cycle

Arg2.RawText: By some accounts on Wall Street and in the industry, the inventory reductions are near an end, which may presage firmer demand

Arg1.RawText: In the latest quarter, at least, profit is expected to fall sharply

Arg2.RawText: For Himont Inc., "how far down it is, we don't know," says Leslie Ravitz at Salomon Brothers

Arg1.RawText: For Himont Inc., "how far down it is, we don't know

Arg2.RawText: The projections are in the neighborhood of 50 cents a share to 75 cents, compared with a restated $1.65 a share a year earlier, when profit was $107.8 million on sales of $435.5 million

Arg1.RawText: Himont faces lower prices for its mainstay product, polypropylene, while it goes forward with a heavy capital investment program to bolster its raw material supply and develop new uses for polypropylene, whose markets include the packaging and automobile industries

Arg2.RawText: The company, based in Wilmington, Del., is 81%-owned by Montedison S.p.A., Milan, which has an offer outstanding for the Himont shares it doesn't already own

Arg1.RawText: At Quantum Chemical Corp., New York, the trouble is lower prices for polyethylene, higher debt costs and the idling of an important plant due to an explosion

Arg2.RawText: Some analysts hedge their estimates for Quantum, because it isn't known when the company will book certain one-time charges

Arg1.RawText: But the estimates range from break-even to 35 cents a share

Arg2.RawText: In the 1988 third quarter, Quantum earned $99.8 million, or $3.92 a share, on sales of $724.4 million

Arg1.RawText: The issue, which is puttable back to the company at par on Oct. 15, 1999, was priced at a spread of 50 basis points above the Treasury's 10-year note

Arg2.RawText: Rated single-A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and single-A by Standard & Poor's Corp., the non-callable issue will be sold through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets

Arg2.RawText: Rated Baa-1 by Moody's and triple-B-plus by S&P, the issue will be sold through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co

Arg1.RawText: The offering, Series 102, backed by Freddie Mac 8 1/2% securities with a weighted average remaining term to maturity of 28.4 years, was priced before the market's afternoon surge

Arg2.RawText: Among classes for which details were available, yields ranged from 8.78%, or 75 basis points over two-year Treasury securities, to 10.05%, or 200 basis points over 10-year Treasurys

Arg1.RawText: The offering, Series 101, is backed by Freddie Mac 9 1/2% securities

Arg2.RawText: Pricing details weren't immediately available

Arg1.RawText: The agency's first strips issue, collateralized by Freddie Mac 8% securities pooled into a single security called a Giant, will be divided into interest-only and principal-only securities

Arg2.RawText: The collateral is being sold by a thrift institution

Arg1.RawText: The collateral is being sold by a thrift institution
